page.description: Use the HTTP method PUT to retrieve the specified URL
page.prototype: Result as P = http_put(url as C [,body as C [,cookie as C [,port as N [,timeout as N [,show_before_send as L [,validate_ssl_cert as L [,SSLCipherList as C]]]]]]])

argument.name: url
argument.description: The address of the server that will receive your data.

argument.name: body
argument.description: The parameters you wish to send. The size of this field is unlimited.

argument.name: timeout
argument.description: Default = 8000 milliseconds. The number of milliseconds to wait before timing out.

argument.name: show_before_send
argument.description: Default = .F.. When .T., displays the request before being sent. Useful for debugging.

argument.name: validate_ssl_cert
argument.description: Default = .T.. If the specified URL starts with "https://", this flag controls whether or not the certificate offered by the server will be validated. If set to .T., the request will always fail. If set to .F., the request may succeed, but the server's identity is not guaranteed.

return.name: Result
return.description: A dot variable containing the server's response.

property.name: error_text
property.description: The error message, if any. If no error occurs, error_text will be empty.

property.name: error_code
property.description: The error number, if any. If no error occurs, error_code will be 0.

property.name: headers
property.description: Response headers. If error_code is 0, the result will contain a dot variable, parsed_headers, with a property representing each response header.

property.name: parsed_headers
property.description: Contains all the headers in the response split out into individual properties. If an error occurred when trying to communicate with the server, parsed_headers will be empty. parsed_headers will always contain the following properties in addition to the headers in the response:

property.name: reason_phrase
property.description: A description of the status code.

property.name: status_code
property.description: The response status code. See [Status Codes] for a list of status codes.

page.discussion: The HTTP_PUT() function requests a URL using HTTP/1.1 PUT. The function returns a pointer with the parsed response from the server. If *[xb:error_code]* is "0", *[xb:parsed_response]* will contain the headers in the result:

section.example: ? result.parsed_headers = AcceptRanges = "none" Allow = "GET, HEAD, OPTIONS, TRACE" Connection = "close" ContentLength = "1293" ContentType = "text/html" Date = "Thu, 22 Dec 2016 23:21:09 GMT" http_version = "HTTP/1.1" reason_phrase = "Method Not Allowed" Server = "Microsoft-IIS/8.5" status_code = 405 XPoweredBy = "ASP.NET"

section.description: Status code 200 indicates that the page exists. Status code 404 indicates that it does not. Other status codes you may encounter, along with the meanings of each, are documented in [Status Codes].

section.note: HTTP_PUT sends using a content type of "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded". To send a request using a different content type, use [HTTP_FETCH()].

section.title: Handling Redirects
section.description: When the server responds with a 30* code, HTTP_PUT() does not automatically use the new URL. The developer needs to examine result.parsed_headers.status_code, then if appropriate, try the URL provided in result.parsed_headers.location. Refer to [HTTP_GET()] for an example.

section.title: Example
section.example:
dim url as c = "www.alphasoftware.com"
dim result as p result = http_put(url)
? result.error_code = 0
? result.parsed_headers.status_code = 405
? result.parsed_headers.reason_phrase = "Method Not Allowed"
a5_show_html(result.body)
